Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Environmentally Friendly Microfiber Polycarbonate Meshes for Continuous Oil Retrieval
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The most commonly used clean-up techniques after an oil spill are in-situ burning, mechanical methods (booms, skimming, and vacuums), and chemical dispersants and/or sorbent materials. Each technique possesses advantages and disadvantages that dictate their use in various oil-spill scenarios. One of the most successful, cost-effective, and versatile methods is the use of porous sorbent materials to remove oil from the surface of a body of water (i.e., an oil absorbing sponge). However, the oil selectivity, reusability, safety, and lack of biodegradability of these synthetic sorbent materials are of significant concern. The goal of this project is to prepare and explore an environmentally friendly, biodegradable oil absorbing sponge for enhanced oil recovery after an oil spill. Different polymer-based materials will be synthesized and characterized in terms of their mechanical and oil-absorbing properties and their biodegradability. In addition to addressing this need for improved environmentally friendly methods to clean up an oil spill, these research activities will train graduate students who will benefit from an interdisciplinary educational experience. These activities will contribute to positive societal outcomes by increasing fundamental scientific knowledge on polymers, educating the workforce in materials science and engineering, and potentially leading to improved polymer-based technologies for today's challenges.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The primary goals of this proposal are to develop an environmentally friendly continuous oil recovery system based on new, biodegradable, safe, and highly tunable poly(glycerol carbonate) meshes, and at the same time educate and train undergraduate and graduate students in a highly interdisciplinary research environment. Specifically, a combined mechanical (skimming/vacuum) and synthetic biodegradable sorbent material system is proposed to retrieve oil after an oil spill that addresses the recovery, reusability, safety, and lack of biodegradability of the current systems. In Objective 1, a library of fatty acid derivatized poly(1,3-glycerol carbonate)s and poly(1,2-glycerol carbonate)s will be synthesized in high yield with molecular weight above 50,000 g/mol via ring-opening polymerization of the corresponding carbonate or epoxide with CO2, respectively, and subsequently characterized. In Objective 2, electrospun polymeric meshes of the poly(glycerol carbonate)s will be fabricated and the oil absorbent, degradation, and mechanical properties will be determined. In Objective 3, the efficiency of oil extraction/recovery using the biodegradable mechanically robust polymeric meshes will be determined in a continuous, vacuum-assisted system and compared to the current gold-standard sorbent (a nonwoven polypropylene mesh). Completion of these objectives will provide: 1) novel synthetic approaches to functionalized poly(1,3-glycerol carbonate)s and poly(1,2-glycerol carbonate)s; 2) correlation of polymer structure on the control of degradation rates; 3) an understanding of the oil and water wettability in highly porous poly(glycerol carbonate) fiber meshes; and 4) design criteria for developing new polymeric materials for enhanced oil recovery after an oil spill.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There are many industrial applications for separating immiscible liquids in a robust, rapid, and environmentally conscious fashion. In particular, the petroleum industry separates aqueous solutions from oleophilic solutions during normal petroleum acquisition or processing, or during accidental petroleum spills. Current techniques to separate these immiscible liquids in an oil spill take advantage of density and surface tension differences to separate, absorb, or otherwise remove oil from oil and water mixtures. However, while these liquids are immiscible, they are often present as stabilized emulsions formed by surfactants naturally found within the oil or the ocean as a result of natural biodegradation causing traditional methods of separation to be lengthy, incomplete, and potentially expensive.

In the case of oil spills, the most commonly used clean-up techniques are in situ burning, mechanical methods (booms, skimming, and vacuums), the use of chemical dispersants and/or sorbent materials. Each technique possesses advantages and disadvantages that dictate their use in various oil spill scenarios. One of the most successful, cost-effective, and versatile methods is the use of porous sorbent materials (e.g., nonwoven polypropylene meshes) to remove oil from the surface of a body of water. However, the oil selectivity, reusability, safety, and lack of biodegradability of these synthetic sorbent materials are of significant concern, and, thus, we developed and evaluated a synthetic biodegradable sorbent material for enhanced oil recovery after an oil spill.

The results from this study provide basic knowledge on the oil absorbent properties of “green” biodegradable meshes for oil recovery as well as establishment of procedures for preparing such meshes. The discovered combined nano-/micro- fiber meshes absorb more oil than nano- or microfiber meshes alone over multiple cycles. Meshes composed of the biodegradable polymer – polycaprolactone perform the best. These new meshes do not yet outperform the current polypropylene meshes (60% of the performance), but they are biodegradable unlike the polypropylene meshes. Continued work in this area by us and other research groups will afford further optimize biodegradable materials for oil retrieval.

In addition to the research activities, this funding supported the training of graduate students. I strive to promote an interdisciplinary educational experience that blends polymers chemistry, materials, and engineering research where engineering and chemistry graduate students are trained to think independently and creatively while collaborating with other experts in this cross-cutting environment.  Also, we participated in outreach activities to the community to share our enthusiasm for basic research. For example, one graduate student participated in the Boston Urban Fellow NSF GK12 Program (2012-2013), where she co-taught a high school science class in a Boston Public School where the majority of the students are underrepresented minorities or economically disadvantaged. Last summer (2104), graduate students Julia Wang and Stacy Chin participated in the Summer Pathways program and hosted 15 female high school students. In the program, Julia and Stacy discussed their research, gave a tour of the laboratory, and described their career path to date and their plans for the future. This summer we are again participating in the Summer Pathways program and hosting a high schools student for an 8 week research stay. Conveying science knowledge, teaching quantitative analytical skills, and sharing enthusiasm for science and engineering is critical to fostering the next generation of students who will attend college or university.
